decision: Adopt Google Cloud Platform (GCP) and Firebase as the core ecosystem, leveraging a serverless architecture with Cloud Functions and Cloud Run.
Use a relational database (PostgreSQL on Cloud SQL) over NoSQL to handle the structured and relational nature of rental data.
Design the database schema using a flexible Entity-Attribute-Value (EAV) model (the 'attributes' system) instead of a rigid, wide-table structure.
Structure the entire project as a monorepo to maintain a single source of truth for shared types and easier dependency management.
Architect the automated data pipeline as a decoupled, event-driven system: Cloud Scheduler -> Orchestrator Function -> Pub/Sub -> Executor Function -> Cloud Run Job.
Develop the frontend as a responsive web app first using React/Vite/TypeScript/TailwindCSS, delaying any consideration of native mobile apps.
Implement a 'no-login, high-frequency, shallow-scrape' strategy for the scraper to maximize data freshness while minimizing the risk of being blocked.
Formalize collaboration with AI agents by creating and maintaining a 'copilot-instructions.md' file as the project's 'constitution'.
Refactor the Pub/Sub-triggered function (Executor) into a standalone Flask/Gunicorn web service to comply with the Cloud Run Gen 2 requirement of listening on a port.
Standardize the deployment process to a strict 'Build then Deploy' model (gcloud builds submit -> gcloud run deploy), eliminating the ambiguous '--source' flag to ensure consistency.
Establish a formal Design System (The Her/Google/Airbnb Synthesis) and a 'Logic First, Aesthetics Second' workflow for building UI components.
Strategically pivot to a 'local-first' scraper development model to accelerate debugging, improve reliability, and reduce initial operational costs.
Re-structure project management from a granular sprint-per-task model to a more strategic, Epic-based model for better clarity.
Build a secure data ingestion API endpoint ('ingest_scraped_data') to act as the bridge between the local scraper and the cloud backend.
Migrate LLM to Gemini Vertex AI (Gemma to Gemini 2.5 Flash Lite via Vertex AI)
Build the QC dashboard UI (Internal admin interface for pending_review listings)
Develop approve/edit/reject functionality (Core state management and approval workflow with ListingForm reuse)
Implement basic filtering system (Public filtering for location, price, attributes)
Adopt custom UI component implementation strategy over external library dependencies when compatibility issues arise
Migrate infrastructure to Vercel (Frontend + Backend) and switch backend framework from Flask to FastAPI for better performance and developer experience.
Implement custom dual-thumb range sliders with mobile-first UX approach for superior touch interaction
